node.text:
“The earth has music for those who listen.” ~ William Shakespeare 🎵

It’s #WorldListeningDay!

How would you describe the earth’s music? What simple, or profound, messages have you received from her?

We give value to the sounds we hear—whether that is through our attention and focus, or the value or perception we afford to that sound. We can also choose to give value to the sound of, by setting aside space for—silence. 

The Grand Canyon provides us an incredible opportunity to listen. We can:
💎 Listen to the brilliant sparkle of the night skies. 
💎 Listen for birds as they express their unique songs, calls, flight patterns or movements.
💎 Listen, and feel for, when the winds start to pick up in their intensity. 
💎 Listen to the gentle caress, or raging roar, of the Colorado River as it continues its timeless generosity and continuous flow. 
💎 Listen to the Canyon open up with wonder, as the golden hues of a sunset paint the horizon in an unearthly awe. 
💎 Listen as a ranger shares with us their passion for the Canyon, as we hear their voice rise with gusto and their palpable excitement. 
💎 Listen to, and learn from, the spoken (or unspoken) histories that intimately connect indigenous people through their sacred connection to this land and this place. 

Silence is not the absence of sound but the presence of one’s ability to listen. So, today, gift yourself some moments for silence. You may find that in silence, you open up to an entire world that is waiting to share in her musical splendor with you!

For additional listening and viewing opportunities from the Grand Canyon, check out our “Minute Out In It” video series, which features compelling stories (told without words) of the diverse soundscapes and landscapes throughout the park. https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/photosmultimedia/minute-out-in-it.htm

- AB

#WorldListeningDay #ListenUp #ListenIn #Soundscapes 

[#VideoDescription: Watching cloud shadows pass lazily across the layers of the canyon during the winter season.]

NPS Video/R. Lane

An audio-described version of the film can be found here: https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=772643A9-9D3B-4B0E-B6DC-D90C1DEB262E

node.title: World Listening Day: Minute Out In It In the Clouds

node.text:
Our Branch Chief of Emergency Services has an important message for you!

Grand Canyon National Park is in an Excessive Heat Warning. Inner Canyon temperatures are reaching as high as 120°F (48.9°C)! 

Your body cannot cool itself or replenish its water or salt in these conditions. Please take a look at this short video addressing heat illness, heat stroke, and how best to visit Grand Canyon during these dog days of summer.

For an audio described version and captions visit: https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=A0226CAB-9569-438C-BD0C-6514B142EF28

For more information on summer hiking visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/planyourvisit/hike-smart.htm

#RecreateResponsibly #HikeSmart

node.text:
As we get ready for Memorial Day Weekend and park visitation increases, we’d like to remind you that May is Wildland Fire Awareness Month. 

As public lands have started announcing fire restrictions in preparation for another hot and dry summer, we want to share with you a story that has become all too common. Whether you want a fire for ambience, heat, or marshmallow roasting, it is incredibly important to know if your fire is legal and safe—fires should never be started to burn waste. 

For more information and current fire restrictions visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/management/firemanagement.htm 

For closed captioned and audio described versions of this video visit: 
https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=813BBAB5-1F03-4702-8823-AF8D16D646FA 

#WildlandFireAwarenessMonth #FireSafety #MemorialDay

node.accessibility_caption: [#ImageDescription: Rainbow sun rays shine down upon a suspension bridge, which crosses over a green-colored Colorado River, with steep cliff rising above the river in February 2021. Photo courtesy of A. Brill]

node.text:
Welcoming that #FridayFeeling!

Bridges, like friendships and relationships, are some of the most important facets of life that connect us as humans. 🌉🤝

Who inspires you to be the best version of yourself? 🌟

Who, in your life, appreciates your inner magic—drawing out your sense of playfulness, adventure, light-heartedness, and FUN? 🤸‍♀️

- AB

[#ImageDescription: Rainbow sun rays shine down upon a suspension bridge, which crosses over a green-colored Colorado River, with steep cliffs rising above the river in February 2021. Photo courtesy of A. Brill]

[#ImageDescription: Shadows of 4 hikers paint the red rocks of the inner canyon along the South Kaibab trail in February 2021. Photo courtesy of A. Brill]

node.accessibility_caption: [#ImageDescription: Rainbow sun rays shine down upon a suspension bridge, which crosses over a green-colored Colorado River, with steep cliff rising above the river in February 2021. Photo courtesy of A. Brill]
[#ImageDescription: Shadows of 4 hikers paint the red rocks of the inner canyon along the South Kaibab trail in February 2021. Photo courtesy of A. Brill]
Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 12, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Our lives offer us many moments to be thankful. 

We can appreciate the daily gift of the sun rising and setting (whether we can see it, or not). We can appreciate the bright beauty of the flowers and plants, thriving and bursting with life, all around us. We can appreciate the delicate marvel of a wren, as she sits daintily perched upon the branches of a bush.

We can appreciate the unexpected twists and turns of our lives, much like the course of a river. As the river steadily flows onward, downstream, she may surprise us. But remember, she’s always creating for us the most direct and easeful path.

We can appreciate the people we meet along the way—for they offer us such unexpected joy, deep mystery, generous support, and an abundance of love to our lives.

On this #ThankfulThursday, we appreciate the opportunity to serve the National Park Service at Grand Canyon National Park. We invite you to simply be and share in the joy of this moment. Thank you.

- AB 🐦

#ThankfulThursday #FindJoy #JoyInTheJourney 

[#ImageDescription: A composite of 3 photos—an October sunset in shades of deep pink paints the sky above a vast and colorful canyon, NPS Photo; a Western Redbud (Cercis occidentalis) blooms along the Tonto Trail on April 3, 2013, NPS Photo/J. Baird; a Canyon Wren (Catherpes mexicanus) sits perched among the branches of a low bush, NPS Photo/A. Kuhn]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 11, 2021. May be an image of tree, nature and sky.

node.text:
Grand Canyon boasts some of the darkest skies in the nation, and given our Gold Tier status as an International Dark Sky Park, visitors may have a great seat to view the Perseid Meteor Shower, peaking late tonight into Thursday morning (8/12).

If skies are clear (unfortunately, it is monsoon season and skies will likely be somewhat cloudy), up to 60 meteors may be seen in an hour—with best viewing from midnight to dawn. However, the moon won’t be obscuring your view. Bonus!

So, find a nice spot and look toward the constellation Perseus (North/Northeast). For help finding it, visit heavens-above.com for an interactive sky map. You can also watch a livestream tonight at go.nasa.gov/2021perseids!
-AR

#Perseids2021 #DarkSkies #FindYourPark

NPS Photo
[#ImageDescription: A brilliant arm of the Milky Way Galaxy juts across a star-filled sky above a rocky cliff edge of Grand Canyon, lined with silhouetted trees.]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 11, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
We understand that not everyone is able to visit Grand Canyon and there are plenty of reasons why…

For some the canyon is too far, for others, the trip is too expensive—this is part of why we want to share photos, videos and other content over social media.
 
We also understand that not everyone feels like national parks are theirs, but rest assured, Grand Canyon and all national park units belong to all of us. We can invest as much or as little time as we like visiting these places. We can choose to be advocates and good stewards of these lands and the stories they tell.
 
We encourage all people to find natural, historical and special places that connect them to the greater story of our nation, and if so inclined, maybe you can work for the National Park Service one day and help shape the narrative yourself! Search for employment opportunities here: USAjobs.gov

We hope to see you soon, online or in person. Until then, find a place near home to enjoy #TrailTuesday.
-AR 

NPS Photo/M.Quinn
[#ImageDescription: (location - Windy Ridge) A path in an immense canyon dappled in sunlight, winds to two viewpoints with visitors gathered at each.]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 11, 2021. May be an image of flower and nature.

node.text:
𝚃𝚑𝚎 𝚖𝚘𝚜𝚝 𝚎𝚡𝚚𝚞𝚒𝚜𝚒𝚝𝚎 𝚓𝚘𝚢
𝙼𝚒𝚐𝚑𝚝 𝚋𝚎 𝚊𝚕𝚒𝚟𝚎
𝚁𝚎𝚊𝚍𝚢 𝚝𝚘 𝚜𝚊𝚢 “𝚑𝚒”
𝚁𝚒𝚐𝚑𝚝 𝚞𝚗𝚍𝚎𝚛 𝚢𝚘𝚞𝚛 𝚏𝚎𝚎𝚝.

𝚂𝚘 𝚕𝚘𝚘𝚔 𝚝𝚘 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚐𝚛𝚘𝚞𝚗𝚍
𝚂𝚎𝚎 𝚠𝚑𝚊𝚝’𝚜 𝚊𝚛𝚘𝚞𝚗𝚍
𝙿𝚊𝚞𝚜𝚎 𝚏𝚘𝚛 𝚊 𝚖𝚘𝚖𝚎𝚗𝚝
𝚈𝚘𝚞 𝚖𝚊𝚢 𝚋𝚎 𝚜𝚞𝚛𝚙𝚛𝚒𝚜𝚎𝚍 𝚋𝚢 𝚠𝚑𝚊𝚝 𝚢𝚘𝚞 𝚜𝚎𝚎!

For this #WildflowerWednesday, we were surprised by this Narrowleaf Penstemon (Penstemon linarioides) flower saying “hi”, while walking into the office. ✨

Flowers can be so delicate, dainty, and fragile. 🌸 Yet, flowers are also hearty, resilient, and strong! 🌿

In what ways are you both delicate and resilient? 

To learn more about Grand Canyon wildflowers, visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/nature/wildflowers.htm 

- AB 

[#ImageDescription: A vibrant purple Narrowleaf Penstemon (Penstemon linarioides) flower springs forth from the rocky desert terrain along the South Rim. NPS Photo/A. Brill]

node.accessibility_caption: Beneath towering canyon walls several thousand feet high, a small brown river merges into a larger dull green river. NPS/Photo

node.text:
On this day, (August 10) in 1869, the Powell Expedition reached the confluence of the Colorado River with the Little Colorado River (Day 79, River Mile 61.5).

"Pulled out at 7 o'clock and ran 14 miles, passing 20 rapids, many of them bad. Came to the mouth of the Flax or Little Colorado River; as disgusting a stream as there is on the continent. 3 rods wide and about 3 ft. deep. Half of its volume and 2/3 of it weight is mud and silt. There are a few mesquite bushes growing on the south side of the Flax River. Walls about 4000 ft. high, inaccessible except on a very few points." —John Colton Sumner.

"We have cut through the sandstones and limestones met in the upper part of the canyon, and through one great bed of marble a thousand feet in thickness. In this, great numbers of caves are hollowed out, and carvings are seen which suggest architectural forms, though on a scale so grand that architectural terms belittle them. As this great bed forms a distinctive feature of the canyon, we call it Marble Canyon.

At two o'clock we reach the mouth of the Colorado Chiquito. This stream enters through a canyon on a scale quite as grand as that of the Colorado itself. It is a very small river and exceedingly muddy and saline. I walk up the stream three or four miles this afternoon, crossing and recrossing where I can easily wade it. Then I climb several hundred feet at one place, and can see for several miles up the chasm through which the river runs." —John Wesley Powell.

#GrandCanyon #Arizona #ColoradoRiver #Expedition #Geology

node.accessibility_caption: Beneath towering canyon walls several thousand feet high, a small brown river merges into a larger dull green river. NPS/Photo
Looking down several thousand feet at the at a small river meandering at the bottom of canyon cliffs. This side canyon on a scale quite as grand as that of the Colorado River itself. NPS/Photo
A spring is gushing from two places and cascading down a sheer and vermilion colored cliff, with ferns and plants surrounding the waterfall. A green river flows beneath the waterfalls.

node.text:
On this day in 1869 (August 9) the first Powell Expedition passed by a spring gushing from the wall of the canyon, which they named Vasey's Paradise (around Colorado River Mile 32) 

"We passed a beautiful cascade today, but the rapids were so furious, and the walls so nearly vertical, we could not stop to examine it. To me, it was the prettiest sight of the whole trip. The green ferns around it formed a pleasing contrast with the unending barrenness of the canyon." —George Young Bradley

"Riding down a short distance, a beautiful view is presented. The river turns sharply to the east and seems enclosed by a wall set with a million brilliant gems. What can it mean? Every eye is engaged, everyone wonders. On coming nearer we find fountains bursting from the rock high overhead, and the spray in the sunshine forms the gems which bedeck the wall. The rocks below the fountain are covered with mosses and ferns and many beautiful flowering plants. We name it Vasey's Paradise, in honor of the botanist who traveled with us last year." —John Wesley Powell [Photo: NPS]

Around the corner, they also came to what we call Redwall Cavern, (Colorado River Mile 33) "The water sweeps rapidly in this elbow of river, and has cut its way under the rock, excavating a vast half-circular chamber, which, if utilized for a theater, would give sitting to 50,000 people. Objection might be raised against it, however, for at high water the floor is covered with a raging flood." —John Wesley Powell [Photo: USGS]

Both locations are popular with today's river trips.

More about river trip opportunities through Grand Canyon National Park. > go.nps.gov/9db0e3

If you wish to camp anywhere in the park, other than in developed campgrounds on the North Rim or the South Rim, you must obtain a permit from the Backcountry Information Center. 
> go.nps.gov/08

#GrandCanyon #MondayMotivation #Arizona #ColoradoRiver #Geology #Whitewater

A closer in view of the spring gushing from two places and cascading down a sheer and vermilion colored cliff, with ferns and plants surrounding the waterfall. A green river flows beneath the waterfalls. NPS Photo
Looking through a vast semi-circular cave past a few tiny people on the shoreline of a river flowing between sheer cliff walls. USGS Photo.
A sideways view of this imense cavern with a few people in the distance. The mouth of the cavern casts a semi-circular shadow across the sand-covered floor of the cavern. USGS Photo.

node.text:
“What you need, what we all need, is silence. Stop the noise in your mind in order for the wondrous sounds of life to be heard.” ~ Thich Nhat Hanh ☮️

On this Mindful Monday, we wanted to share a poem born out of such inspiration to listen, observe and fully receive life as it is happening in this moment. 

🌊River Flow 
I feel these rush of energies ✨
Pass through my body 
The water steadily carving out 
Her own path and way 
Nothing to stop her 
Just an endless flow 
A steady commitment to her path 
Onward! 
Downstream, relaxed in her existence 
Carrying, carving out 
Greeting her existence 
Alive and full of life 
Swirling with surprises 
Breathe in your tranquil depths 
As we welcome to us, this new day!

What moments in your life have you felt a similar sense of peace wash over you?
 
- AB

#MindfulMonday #Mindfulness #NatureAbundance #ListenIn #Appreciation 

[#ImageDescription: At sunrise, a waterfall gently flows over a bed of shadowed rocks with views of a narrow, red-colored canyon in the background. NPS Photo/A. Wilson]

node.accessibility_caption: From a calm stretch of river, a series of colorful cliffs rise to form a vast canyon landscape with fluffy summer clouds above in a deep blue sky. “Sentinels of Time” 30 by 40 inches, acrylic, ©2021, John D Cogan.

node.text:
“Sentinels of Time” by John D Cogan, 30 by 40 inches, acrylic, ©2021, 38 by 48 framed. 

"Anyone who has rafted the Colorado River knows, that when viewed from the inside out, the Grand Canyon seems almost to be a separate and distinct place. The temples, buttes and walls, once observed from the rim, rising out of the depths, now tower above, even more massive and commanding. 

Like the River, time seems to mostly drift by, each bend and turn presenting new vistas in front and behind. But there are surprises, the churning white water of rapids, the changes in geologic strata as the chasm deepens, and glimpses of inhabitants who make the Canyon their home. One thing is always constant for the artist: whether looking into it or out of it, the Grand Canyon never disappoints." — John D Cogan, Artist  @johndcogan
 
The 13th Annual Celebration of Art will take place September 11, 2021 - January 17, 2022. 

Since 2009, Celebration of Art (CoA) has invited participating artists to paint “en plein air” (outside on location) for a week at the canyon. The works produced from the event will be available for purchase online and on display at historic Kolb Studio for a four-month sale and exhibition beginning Sunday, September 19, 2021.

CoA is a wonderful tradition at Grand Canyon National Park, providing a vibrant experience for visitors, a venue for artists inspired by the canyon, and a successful fundraiser to benefit a dedicated art venue and arts programming at the park. For this year's event, we are welcoming back all of our 2020 artists, including John D Cogan. 

https://www.grandcanyon.org/events/celebration-of-art/ @grand_canyon_conservancy

node.text:
Echoes from the Canyon Radio Hour presents: 

GRAND CANYON MYSTERIES

A new podcast episode featuring tall tales, disappearances, folklore, and unfathomable mysteries from Grand Canyon. 

go.nps.gov/echo 

#History #HistoryMemes #GrandCanyon #Arizona #StoryTime #StoryTelling #OralHistory #PodcastersOfInstagram #Podcast #Podcasting #NationaParks #NationalPark

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 06, 2021. May be an image of nature and tree.

node.text:
You know, we spend a lot of time showing off the South Rim of Grand Canyon, but we are past due for a North Rim spotlight. ✨

From the rolling meadows at the entrance, to the wildflowers that hug the dense green forests, the North Rim is much more than 𝘢𝘯𝘰𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘳 𝘷𝘪𝘦𝘸 𝘰𝘧 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘤𝘢𝘯𝘺𝘰𝘯. 

Many venture to the taller side (1000 feet above the South Rim) of Grand Canyon to escape the crowds, beat (though not that well this season) the heat, and to experience a more expansive and gradual view of the canyon's depths. Over a 4 hour drive from the Village on the South Rim, the North Rim is close to many park units like Glen Canyon National Recreation Area, Vermillion Cliffs National Monument and Zion National Park. 

Some may say that the North Rim is the "best rim", and whereas we don’t like to take too much stock in that assessment…we won’t say we disagree. 

-a South Rim Ranger (AR)

#FindYourPark #GrandCanyon #FridayFeeling
NPS Photos/ A. Rehkopf

node.text:
#FridayFeeling

Leaping into the weekend…and our own natural beauty! 💖

“When we accept our own wild beauty, it is put into perspective, and we are no longer poignantly aware of it anymore, but neither would we forsake it or disclaim it either. Does a wolf know how beautiful she is when she leaps? Does a feline know what beautiful shapes she makes when she sits? Is a bird awed by the sound it hears when it snaps open its wings? Learning from them, we just act in our own true way and do not draw back from or hide our natural beauty. Like the creatures, we just are, and it is right.” ~ Clarissa Pinkola Estés

Grand Canyon is home to 91 species of mammals, 447 known species of birds, 48 species of reptiles, 10 species of amphibians, plus insects, spiders, and more.

To learn more about wildlife at Grand Canyon, visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/nature/wildlife.htm

- AB

[#ImageDescription: A red fox (Vulpes vulpes) takes a giant leap with its focus intent on the snow-covered ground below. NPS Photo/N. Herbert, Yellowstone National Park]

[#ImageDescription: A California condor (Gymnogyps californianus), with wings spread, soars over a colorful canyon with a clear blue sky above. NPS Photo]

[#ImageDescription: A bobcat (Lynx rufus) kitten, with large eyes and ears, perched in a tree, looks at the camera. NPS Photo/E. Hope]
